item.title: I have been reviewing the CEBRA paper in depth. What really strikes me is the multi-sessions/animal embedding. I feel like this paper is only scratching the surface of what could be done there. For starter, we could embed across species or even between models and experiments.
item.description: I have been reviewing the CEBRA paper in depth. What really strikes me is the multi-sessions/animal embedding. I feel like this paper is only scratching the surface of what could be done there. For starter, we could embed across species or even between models and experiments.
item.content:encoded: I have been reviewing the CEBRA paper in depth. What really strikes me is the multi-sessions/animal embedding. I feel like this paper is only scratching the surface of what could be done there. For starter, we could embed across species or even between models and experiments.

item.title: In addition, I wonder if it could also be used for transfer training from experiment to models?
item.description: In addition, I wonder if it could also be used for transfer training from experiment to models?
item.content:encoded: In addition, I wonder if it could also be used for transfer training from experiment to models?

item.title: I also would like to see this applied against key behavior variables like rewards or prediction errors...
item.description: I also would like to see this applied against key behavior variables like rewards or prediction errors...
item.content:encoded: I also would like to see this applied against key behavior variables like rewards or prediction errors...

item.title: Making embedding robust against behavior is essentially what the cortex is probably trying to do inherently so the algorithm itself might have biological relevance...
item.description: Making embedding robust against behavior is essentially what the cortex is probably trying to do inherently so the algorithm itself might have biological relevance...

item.title:
How does a mussel shell open and shut easily and without damage for hundreds of thousands of cycles during the bivalve’s lifetime?
The answer lies in a combination of design and materials that resist brittle fracture over time, a new Science study finds. https://t.co/1vZClAndf6 https://t.co/iW3AJ93DVD

item.title: Belphegor's prime is the palindromic prime number corresponding to (10³⁰ + 666 × 10¹⁴ + 1). The number itself contains superstitious elements: it has 666 at its heart, it's surrounded on either side by 13 zeroes and is 31 digits in length (13 reversed) https://t.co/l2otGJpidT https://t.co/XgR4eLU3Ho
